Dear colleagues,
As I think you know, a week ago I had a pretty severe bicycling accident on my way home from work. The accident itself is a bit of a mystery; as far as I know, I wasn‚Äôt hit by a car or anything but nonetheless ended up hitting the ground with my head, and really only my head, at full speed.
I have some tendency to keep parts of my life experience away from Caltech Library, partly because I have found it easier to be a manager and archivist if I let others project some assumptions onto me rather than always expressing myself fully. In this situation, though, I‚Äôm finding that I want to share a lot of my experience of disability and being a patient, as well my uncertainty about what my body will be like in the future. I‚Äôm writing this paragraph in part to warn that the next one is a bit visceral; there‚Äôs a very serious but hidden injury involved.
I imagine my helmet effectively protected my skull, but my face was badly hurt; I didn‚Äôt break my nose or cheek bones, but I tore up the skin a lot and then got some very impressive plastic surgery in the ER. Also, the force also apparently travelled into my spine and fractured two neck vertebrae. Those in turn damaged the nerves in my spine, limiting my brain‚Äôs ability to communicate with parts of my body, particularly my right leg and hand.
There are two types of good news: First, for whatever reason I immediately felt comfortable with the idea that my body might never be the same as it was. I have some philosophical thoughts on why this feels okay, and I‚Äôll probably share them in bits, but it also has felt closely tied to my work at Caltech with histories of eugenics and recognizing the dignity and validity of the lives of people with disabilities, with perceiving bodily difference without accepting impositions of hierarchy, and with the great accessibility work many colleagues have been pursuing in the library as well. The second type of good news, which I feel in some tension to the first, is that in the overall population of people with spinal injuries, I have retained a large amount of control over my body, and am rapidly learning to build up more control. I don‚Äôt know when or if I will walk without a walker, ride a bike, type, or handle a printed book as dexterously as I used to, but I might do all those things within months, or I might do some and adopt alternatives for others. I might even break with my existing habits of transportation in LA and buy a car!
The other good news is that Huntington Hospital has an excellent rehab program for spinal injury patients, so I‚Äôm here likely for a few weeks doing training with incredible physical and occupational therapists.

Kewing: You‚Äôve already read this in an email, Pete, but I decided to share it. 
In the early 50s, my dad worked for the Canton newspaper. When he was diagnosed with a spinal abscess, the company took care of all of his medical expenses (paternalistic but very helpful) and sent him three times, I think, to what was then called the Institute of Medical and Physical Rehabilitation (IPMR), a part of New York University Medical School. After several surgeries, he lost the use of his legs but learned life skills at IPMR. 
In 1984, the name was changed to the Rusk Institute of Medical Rehabilitation.
That‚Äôs honoring Howard A. Rusk, who established IPMR at NYU in 1950 and who‚Äôs considered the founder of rehabilitation medicine. He had served in the Air Force during the war and became interested in rehabilitation when working with injured airmen. If you look him up on Wikipedia, you‚Äôll see a photo of him with Roy Campanella, the Dodgers catcher who was injured in a car accident in 1958. My dad was at the Institute at the same time, and he knew Dr. Rusk as well.
There‚Äôs also a YouTube video of an old interview with Dr. Rusk about visiting Korea more than once and trying to help Koreans disabled during the war. He was much honored and quite a pioneer. His memoir is called A World to Care For.
All these developments were precursors to the disability movement, I think. My dad used to say that handicapped people (the term we used at the time) mostly stayed in their houses. Very few restaurants or public facilities were accessible. When we on rare occasions went to restaurants as a family, we were pretty conspicuous: you just didn‚Äôt see wheelchairs in public places. Dr. Rusk‚Äôs efforts attempted to counter this. He believed every person with a disability would benefit from therapy (and he included psychological therapy), and most could probably work again.
I wonder if anyone on your medical team has heard of him. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised either way.
My dad also wrote some things about his stays at the Institute and the rehabilitation he underwent there, which I can send if you want. He learned to pretty much take care of himself, which in earlier eras I don‚Äôt think would have been possible. He also started a social club for people with disabilities. 
When I was telling your mom some of this, she thought you would be interested, and I thought so, too. You‚Äôre reminding me of my dad in another way as well: your attitude toward your recovery and what‚Äôs happened. A friend wrote to my dad once that he‚Äôd never seen my dad‚Äôs ‚Äúchin droop.‚Äù Of course, your chin might droop now and then, but I can echo what everyone‚Äôs saying on this site, that you‚Äôre inspiring.
